item.title: Trump’s Order Aims to Boost Ingredient Used in Roundup
item.description: An executive order aimed at ramping up production of glyphosate set off alarms among supporters of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Regis Duvignau/Reuters
item.media:description: The weedkiller Roundup, whose active ingredient is glyphosate, is used by farmers around the world.

item.title: Justice Dept. Lawyer Is Found in Contempt by Federal Judge
item.description: The ruling out of Minnesota marks a new level of judicial concern about the Trump administration’s lack of compliance with judges’ orders in immigration cases.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Seamus Hughes
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department has admitted violations in cases involving immigrants’ challenging the legality of their detention.

item.title: Texas Congressman’s Aide Told Co-Worker of Affair Before Killing Herself
item.description: The co-worker, who no longer works for Representative Tony Gonzales, shared screenshots of the text exchange with The New York Times. Mr. Gonzales accused his Republican primary challenger of being behind the revelation.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tony Gonzales in Washington this month.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.description: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jonathan Klein/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, seen here in the North Sea last year, is making its way toward the Middle East.

item.title: As ICE Buys Up Warehouses, Even Some Trump Voters Say No
item.description: The agency is ramping up arrests, but local pushback is complicating efforts to expand detention capacity and prevent overcrowding.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Hamed Aleaziz and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stacy Bradley, right, and Sarah Wellman in the parking lot of their cheerleading gym in Surprise, Ariz. The federal government plans to convert the warehouse at right into a detention center for immigrants.

item.title: Officials Violated Court Orders on Immigration in New Jersey, Justice Dept. Tells Judge
item.description: The violations stemmed from immigration cases. Judges across the country have expressed alarm about illegal transfers and missed deadlines.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Zach Montague and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside Delaney Hall detention center in Newark, N.J., in December.

item.title: Texas Election Season Heats Up as Early Voting in Senate Primaries Begins
item.description: Both parties’ Senate primary races are kicking into high gear.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: State Representative James Talarico.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.description: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane belonging to Donald J. Trump arrived at Palm Beach International Airport in 2023. Florida Republicans have advanced an effort to rename the airport “President Donald J. Trump International Airport.”

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.description: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has made efforts to roll back regulations for worker safety and protections, including plans to pull back a requirement that employers provide appropriate lighting at construction sites.

item.title: Journalists Arrested in Cameroon While Covering Secretive U.S. Deportations
item.description: An Associated Press reporter was hit and held with three other journalists and a lawyer, two detainees said, while at a center for migrants secretively deported from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: The compound where deportees from the United States were being held in Yaoundé, Cameroon.

item.title: Leslie Wexner Says Epstein ‘Conned’ Him, but Democrats Are Skeptical
item.description: House Republicans skipped a deposition with Leslie Wexner, the retail billionaire, and Democrats said his answers were not credible.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Joshua A. Bickel/Associated Press
item.media:description: Representative Robert Garcia of California, the top Democrat on the House Oversight Committee, speaking during a news conference about the congressional deposition of Les Wexner in New Albany, Ohio.

item.title: Administration Targets Noncitizen Voting, Despite Finding It Rare
item.description: The intensified push is part of an extraordinary all-fronts effort to insert federal law enforcement into the machinery of American elections ahead of the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Devlin Barrett, Alan Feuer, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Miami Beach in 2024. A new nationwide effort by the Trump administration to find and charge criminal voting cases appears to be targeted at green card holders.

item.title: N.I.H. Director Will Temporarily Run C.D.C. in Leadership Shake-Up
item.description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya will serve as the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention until President Trump appoints a permanent director.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the director of the National Institutes of Health, will serve as the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Meta Begins $65 Million Election Push to Advance A.I. Agenda
item.description: Meta’s biggest election investment aims to prevent state legislation that it fears could inhibit artificial intelligence development. Its spending starts this week in Texas and Illinois.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Matt Zdun
item.category: American Technology Excellence Project (Political Action Committee)
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta is quietly supporting two new super PACs as it aims to influence the regulatory environment for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Colorado Democrats Push to Rip Up 2028 House Map for an Extra Edge
item.description: A proposed ballot measure to give Democrats more seats for the 2028 and 2030 elections signals that the nation’s gerrymandering fight is likely to persist for years.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jason Connolly/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Voters in Oak Creek, Colo., in 2024. A ballot measure backed by a Democratic-allied group in the state would ask voters to suspend the state’s independent redistricting commission for two election cycles and install a map with as many as three more Democratic-leaning seats.

item.title: A Case Against 6 Democrats Lacked Urgency. Then Came a Swift Bid for an Indictment.
item.description: Prosecutors have been repeatedly caught between the president’s insistence that they undertake weak or baseless cases and the necessity of having to go to court.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senators Elissa Slotkin and Mark Kelly were among the Democratic lawmakers targeted by federal prosecutors after recording a video informing troops that they could refuse illegal orders.

item.title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Ryan Remiorz/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Moderna’s vaccine production facility in Laval, Quebec.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.description: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Drivers for Uber, Lyft and other taxi services are often the biggest users of charging stations, like this one at Kennedy International Airport.

item.title: An Architect of Virginia’s Redistricting Will Run for a New Seat Himself
item.description: Dan Helmer, a Democratic state lawmaker, played a key role in putting redrawn congressional maps before state voters.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Salwan Georges for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Army veteran of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, Dan Helmer, 44, entered state politics in 2019 on a platform of gun control and abortion rights.

item.title: Democrats Plan to Counter Trump’s State of the Union Speech With Rally
item.description: The House Democratic leader has asked rank-and-file members to sit quietly at the speech or skip it altogether, wary of creating a distraction.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Al Green, Democrat of Texas, was ejected from the chamber after disrupting President Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress last year.
